content: The "Small Business Investment Company Amendments Act of 2001" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions regarding subsidy fees. SEC. 2. SUBSIDY FEES amended to increase the fee amount to 1.38 percent per year and extend the deadline to September 30, 2001. Effective date is October 1, 2001. SEC. 3. CONFLICTS OF INTEREST amended by removing disclosure requirement in the locality most directly affected by the transaction. SEC. 4. PENALTIES FOR FALSE STATEMENTS. The text chunk discusses amendments to criminal and civil penalties related to small business investment companies and the Small Business Administration. It includes changes to sections of the United States Code and the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act of 1989. The text chunk adds a new section to the Small Business Act and specifies the effective date for the amendment. SEC. 5. REMOVAL OR SUSPENSION OF MANAGEMENT OFFICIALS. Amends Section 313 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 to define 'management official' and outline the process for their removal. The Act includes regulations, cease-and-desist orders. The Act includes regulations for removing a management official who has breached fiduciary duties involving personal dishonesty. A notice of intention to remove must be provided with a statement of facts, and a hearing will be held within 30 to 60 days. The Administrator can set a new date for a hearing at the request of the management official or the Attorney General. If the management official does not appear at the hearing, they will be deemed to have consented to the order of removal. The Administrator may issue orders of removal if any grounds specified in the notice have been established. The Administrator may issue orders of removal from office if grounds specified in the notice have been established. Such orders become effective after 30 days and remain enforceable unless stayed, modified, terminated, or set aside by the Administrator or a reviewing court. Additionally, the Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit participation. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or prohibit management officials from participating in licensee affairs for protection or Administration interests. The suspension or prohibition becomes effective upon notice and remains in effect pending administrative proceedings. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit management officials from participating in licensee affairs for protection or Administration interests. The suspension or prohibition remains in effect until charges are dismissed or an order of removal is issued. Management officials can seek judicial review for a stay of suspension or prohibition. The Administrator can suspend or prohibit management officials from participating in licensee affairs if charged with a felony involving dishonesty or breach of trust. The suspension or prohibition remains until resolved, and judicial review can be sought for a stay. The Administrator has the authority to remove a management official upon conviction of a felony, with the removal becoming effective upon service of the order. A not guilty finding does not prevent the Administrator from taking action to suspend or remove the official. The Administrator has the authority to suspend or remove a management official from office, or prohibit their participation in the affairs of the licensee. Notices served to the official must also be served to the licensee. Hearings will be held in the district where the licensee is located and will follow procedural provisions outlined in title 5, United States Code. After a hearing, the Administrator will issue a decision within 90 days, including findings of fact and orders consistent with the provisions of title 5, United States Code. The Administrator has the authority to modify, terminate, or set aside any order issued under this section at any time, unless a petition for review is filed in a court of appeals. Judicial review of an order issued under this section shall be exclusively as provided in this subsection. Any party to a hearing may obtain a review of any order by filing in the court of appeals. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit allows parties to petition for modification, termination, or setting aside of an Administrator's order within 30 days. The court has exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside the order after receiving the petition and the record from the Administrator. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has exclusive jurisdiction to review and make final judgments on petitions to affirm, modify, terminate, or set aside orders issued by the Administrator. Judicial review proceedings shall follow the procedures outlined in chapter 7 of title 5, United States Code, and the Supreme Court may review the judgment and decree upon certiorari. The commencement of judicial review does not automatically stay any orders issued by the Administrator. SEC. 6. REDUCTION OF FEES. Two-Year Reduction of Section 7(a) Fees: Guarantee fees under the Small Business Act are amended for a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002. The guarantee fee percentages vary based on the total loan amount. The Small Business Act is amended to reduce annual fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002. Additionally, Section 504 fees under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 are also reduced. The Small Business Act is amended to reduce annual fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002. The Administration may not assess or collect any up front guarantee fee for loans made under this title during the same period. The Small Business Act is amended to reduce annual fees for loans approved during a 2-year period starting October 1, 2002. The amendments made by this section to section 503 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 shall be effective only to the extent that funds are made available under appropriations Acts.
